title: Biden Close to Picking Fed Chief; Fed Views on Inflation Response Differ; Consumers Keep Spending
text:
Top News

Biden Says Fed Chair Pick Could Be Unveiled This Week

When asked whether he was any closer to a decision on who will lead the Federal Reserve, President Biden said, "You're going to hear that in about four days." After Mr. Biden's comment, a White House official said the president would make his decision before Thanksgiving, Nov. 25, which suggests the announcement might instead slip into next week.

Senate Banking Committee Chairman Sherrod Brown (D., Ohio) told reporters Tuesday he was "absolutely certain" that either Mr. Powell or Ms. Brainard would be confirmed by the Senate. "They're both clearly qualified."

Two Fed Officials at Odds Over How to Deal With Inflation

Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis President James Bullard said the U.S. central bank needs to move more forcefully to confront high levels of inflation, while San Francisco Fed leader Mary Daly stressed that moves to tamp down on price pressures prematurely could cause unneeded pain later should those pressures weaken.

Treasurys Edge Toward Stability After Inflation-Driven Selloff

U.S. Economy

Retail Sales Rose by 1.7% in October Despite High Inflation

American consumers withstood rising inflation to power a strong start to the holiday shopping season, with big retailers reporting higher sales and expectations for a solid finish to the year. Sales at U.S. retail stores, online sellers, and restaurants rose by a seasonally adjusted 1.7% in October compared with the previous month, the Commerce Department said.

Walmart Raises Forecast and Says Shelves Are Stocked for Holidays

Biden's New Deal Ambitions Run Into Political, Economic Constraints

There are big differences between the political and economic landscape Franklin D. Roosevelt faced and the present day that have already circumscribed President Biden's plans and raise questions about their durability.

Government Could Be Unable to Pay Bills as Soon as Dec. 15: Yellen

https://www.wsj.com/articles/federal-government-could-be-unable-to-pay-bills-as-soon-as-dec-15-yellen-says-11637103882

The U.S. government could run out of resources to meet the nation's obligations as soon as Dec. 15, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said yesterday, reviving questions about how Congress will resolve a standoff about raising or suspending the federal borrowing limit.

Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac to Back Home Loans of Nearly $1 Million

The federal government is about to back mortgages of nearly $1 million for the first time. The maximum size of home-mortgage loans eligible for backing by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are expected to jump sharply in 2022, a reflection of the rapid appreciation in home prices nationally over the past year.

Key Developments Around the World

Bank of Canada Flags Uncertainties About Labor-Market Recovery

Uncertainty about Canada's labor-market recovery will make it harder to determine when the economy has reached full employment and interest rates can start to rise, Bank of Canada deputy governor Lawrence Schembri said.

UK Inflation Hits Highest Level in a Decade

Annual inflation in the U.K. accelerated in October, reaching the highest level since December 2011, fueled by higher energy prices and supply-chain disruptions. The consumer-price index increased 4.2% on the year.

Bank Indonesia Likely to Leave Benchmark Rate Unchanged, Poll Says

Bank Indonesia is likely to keep its seven-day reverse repo rate unchanged at 3.5% at its November meeting, according to all seven analysts polled by The Wall Street Journal. The economy is in a relative sweet spot that will allow the central bank to maintain its accomodative monetary policy, Mizuho says. Indonesia's economic growth seems to be picking up while inflationary pressure seems to be under control, it says. The rate decision is due Thursday. (Dow Jones Newswires)

Financial Regulation Roundup

U.S. to Sell Cryptocurrency Seized in BitConnect Fraud Scheme

A judge agreed to a request from U.S. authorities to liquidate roughly $56 million in proceeds seized from a U.S. promoter of offshore company BitConnect, which allegedly conducted one of the biggest scams ever involving cryptocurrencies.

Son of Former Panama President Plans to Plead Guilty in Bribery Case

Luis Enrique Martinelli, the son of Panama's former president, appeared in federal court in Brooklyn, N.Y., on Tuesday and said he would plead guilty to taking part in a bribery scheme involving Brazil's Odebrecht SA.

Forward Guidance

Wednesday (all times ET)

8:30 a.m.: U.S. Commerce Department releases October housing starts

9 a.m.: European Central Bank's Schnabel speaks on euro area economic and monetary policy outlook at event hosted by Goldman Sachs

9:10 a.m.: New York Fed's Williams speaks at U.S. Treasury Market Conference

12:40 p.m.: Cleveland Fed's Mester gives opening remarks at financial stability conference organized by Cleveland Fed and Office of Financial Research; Fed's Waller speaks on stablecoins at financial stability conference organized by Cleveland Fed and Office of Financial Research; San Francisco Fed's Daly speaks with Commodities Futures Trading Commission acting chair at U.S. Treasury Market Conference

4:05 p.m.: Chicago Fed's Evans speaks on economy and monetary policy at Mid-Size Bank Coalition of America event

4:10 p.m.: Atlanta Fed's Bostic speaks on assistance for vulnerable renters at Fed community development research seminar

Thursday

Time N/A: Central Bank of the Republic of Turkey releases policy statement; South African Reserve Bank releases policy statement; Bank Indonesia releases policy statement

5 a.m.: European Central Bank's Panetta speaks at hearing on the digital euro before Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament

7:30 a.m.: Atlanta Fed's Bostic speaks on regional outlook at Metro Atlanta Chamber meeting

9:30 a.m.: New York Fed's Williams, European Central Bank's Lane speak on new Fed and ECB strategies at European Commission, New York Fed and Centre for Economic Policy Research webinar

12:30 p.m.: San Francisco Fed's Daly speaks at Fed Listens event on pandemic Recovery and the role of care work

2 p.m.: Chicago Fed's Evans speaks on economy and monetary policy at BKD Financial Services Symposium

Research

JPMorgan Raises Fourth-Quarter GDP Growth Forecast to 5%

JPMorgan is upgrading its expectations for fourth-quarter U.S. gross domestic product growth to 5%, from 4%, in the wake of robust retail sales data. "Real consumer spending took a little breather in 3Q after expanding at a double-digit annualized pace in the first two quarters of the year, but after that pause, 4Q consumption growth so far looks to be back on track," wrote Michael Feroli, an economist at the bank. "Growth this quarter should also benefit from the long-awaited turnaround in inventory investment, particularly in the motor vehicle sector," he said.

Commentary

Gloom Over Holiday Sales Looks Inflated

If Americans are feeling glum, they sure are engaging in some retail therapy, writes Justin Lahart. A pickup in retail sales in October stands in contrast to surveys that show consumers have become downbeat.

Ample savings and continued employment growth, it seems, can have more influence on how much people spend than how they feel about the world on any particular day. The strength of sales in October also suggests that despite continuing supply-chain issues, holiday sales will be good.

Basis Points

Industrial production in the U.S. rose in October, reflecting a strong bounce back in activity following the weather-induced fall registered the prior month, but supply-chain bottlenecks continued to limit manufacturing output. Industrial production—which includes factory, mining and utility output—increased at a seasonally adjusted 1.6% in October compared with the previous month, according to data from the Federal Reserve released Tuesday. (DJN)

German regulators on Tuesday suspended certification proceedings for a natural-gas pipeline from Russia, adding to concerns Europe will run low on fuel this winter. Prices for the heating and power-generation fuel shot higher around the world in response. Futures gained more than 15% in Europe. U.S. prices added 3.2%.

Global trade flows fell slightly in September, a reflection of blockages in supply chains as factories and logistics networks struggle to meet strong consumer demand.

Japan's exports increased in October for the eighth consecutive month, driven by demand for mineral fuels, steel and semiconductor related products in key overseas markets, Ministry of Finance data showed Wednesday.

Tanzania's economy grew by 4.7% in the first half of this year, the country's central bank said late Tuesday. "The external sector is improving from the negative effects of the pandemic, sustaining a low current account deficit, as export proceeds of minerals, cash crops and tourism started to flow in," the bank said in a monetary policy statement. (DJN)
